people.description:
Principal Investigator. Curriculum Vitae.
For more information, please visit my website.

Ph.D. Physics, Harvard University. MPhys. Oxford University
I am a postdoc in the Applied Physics department. I am interested in most aspects of theoretical neurobiology, and am currently studying models of complex synapses. My profile.

Ph.D. Biophysics, UC Berkeley
I am a Visiting Scholar in Surya's lab at Stanford and an Academic Resident at Khan Academy. I study machine learning, human learning, and neuroscience. My webpage is http://sohldickstein.com/.

B.S. Engineering Physics, Cornell University
I am a PhD Candidate in the Applied Physics department. Generally, I am interested in applying mathematical methods to understand biological systems. My research has primarily been focused on theoretical neuroscience, high dimensional theoretical statistics and machine learning, and statistical physics. For more information visit my website.

B.S. Physics and B.S. Neurobiology, U.C. Berkeley
I'm a graduate student in the bioengineering department coadvised by Prof. Surya Ganguli and Prof. Kwabena Boahen. I have worked on a variety of problems since starting graduate school. I'm currently studying how neural dynamics are embedded in their high-dimensional phase space.

B.S. Math and B.S. Neuroscience, College of William and Mary
I'm a graduate student in the Neurosciences program here at Stanford, coadvised by Prof. Surya Ganguli and Prof. Lisa Giocomo. I am interested in the way that neural networks encode information about the world. Currently, I am working on understanding the neural mechanisms that generate and support the accurate firing patterns exhibited by grid cells, neurons found in medial entorhinal cortex that are thought to encode spatial location.

B.S. Biomedical & Electrical Engineering, Duke University
I am a graduate student in the Neurosciences program here at Stanford. I am interested in neural coding and sensory neuroscience. Currently, I am working on understanding how the retina, the first stage of visual processing, encodes natural images. I work closely with the Baccus lab here at Stanford. You can read more at my website.
people.additional:
NSF Graduate Research Fellow.
Bio-X Honorary Fellow.

people.description:
B.S. Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University
I'm a graduate student in the Computer Science Department. My research aims to utilize machine learning techniques to better understand how information is processed in the brain, and to use these insights to build more intelligent models that can be applied to large high-dimensional datasets. Find out more on my website.
